Imagine if someone took RuneScape, removed all the parts where you actually have to play the game, and left you with pure, distilled number-watching satisfaction. That's Melvor Idle, and I've sunk 146 hours into it like a proper numpty.

This game is basically a legal form of gambling with your time. You set it up, walk away, come back, and suddenly your character has mined 47,000 iron ore while you were at work pretending to be productive. It's like having a very dedicated virtual employee who never asks for a raise or takes a sick day, eh?

The skill system is absolutely massive - 20+ skills to max out, and each one feels like climbing Mount Logan in your underwear during February. The combat is deceptively deep for an idle game, and I've died to bosses I thought I had figured out more times than I care to admit.

Published by Jagex (yes, THE Jagex), so you know there's some proper RuneScape DNA in here. If you've ever played OSRS, you'll feel right at home, except you can finally go outside while still making progress.

Perfect for anyone who wants to feel like they're accomplishing something while actually doing absolutely nothing. 10/10, would leave running in the background forever again.

[b]Intro[/b]

Idle games are a type of management game in which you assign a task to complete and in some cases choose equipment, bonuses, etc. for your agents. Melvor Idle is (apparently) based on the MMORPG Runescape. But instead of enduring grinding and enjoying combat, you just sit back and give orders.

[b]Review[/b]

So, here's the thing. Who is this for? All you do is click "Mining" and select something to mine. Or you click "Crafting" and click something to craft. The most engaging thing is combat, and even that can be automated almost entirely. There's also not a lot of depth to this. The only options in combat are melee, ranged and magic, and the barrier and abyssal variants of those. You don't really need to think about the right equipment, spells, prayers, etc. because almost always you just pick the "best" stuff you have.

Still, i had some fun with this. With minimal effort you can grow a character and a town. There are all kinds of items, skills and enemies to engage with. Mostly i just like to see the systems and elements game designers come up with. And Melvor has a ton of those. It's niche but it's nice.

If Runescape is like addicting cigarettes, Melvor Idle is like vaping. You have similar dopamine hits, but instead of sitting there all day jumping from rooftop or rooftop, clicking on regenerating trees over and over, or moving periodically so the crabs can continue beating on you and you don't get caught by the AFK timer, you can simply let Melvor Idle run in the background. So it's a lot less destructive to your actual time and maybe even your health.

If you're a fan of the Idle genre, just know that this isn't a traditional idle game. There isn't a huge progression curve where numbers grow outrageously out of control. Or prestige mechanics. etc. Basically this game is exactly how it is advertised: a distillation of Runescape down to its core elements. 

I'm enjoying my playthrough so far. I highly recommend the Ancients Relic mode that comes with one of the DLC, as it's the kind of gameplay mode that offers extra challenge (the skill cap), but you end up with better rewards (the relics). You can't just over train everything, the mode forces you to engage with the game mechanics and systems and gives you actual walls to overcome. In compensation you get crazy good bonuses you wouldn't be able to get if you played it in normal mode.

My only criticism of the game 400 hours in, is that inventory space and gold gate the early game too much. I feel like early-game you are too limited by inventory space and the gold costs of everything. And then suddenly when you get your thieving system setup in the right way, that problem literally can disappear overnight, as you find yourself with hundreds of millions... even billions of gold and are buying inventory upgrades at cap price like your daily morning Starbucks coffee.

The game is very well tuned. Getting +50 HP when you have like 800, or an extra 3% damage reduction doesn't seem like much, especially if you are used to other Idle games prostituting exponential and and multiplicative increases to you. But it DOES makes a difference and sometimes that difference means being able to idle a dungeon with no effort to franctically sitting there for 12 minutes clicking on your food like a sweaty gamer exactly the moment your auto attack timer rolls over. I always appreciate when a game is tuned so that small upgrades can make the world of difference.

I do think skills like Astrology and Cartography should have been passive skills like township and farming, as these are both things that take incredibly amounts of time, offer very little game play other than waiting for the skill to train, yet are necessary because they tie into so much other stuff. 

Just my two cents. Melvor Idle 2 is coming out, so I'm interested to see how the dev iterated on the systems they put in place here.

I've played a bunch of idle games. This one is the best hands down. It takes the heart of what makes an MMO fun, and distills it down to it's most basic level. There's no 3D world, there's not character, but you still have the level/collect/quest grinds. That satisfaction of increasing your skills, and using them to craft items that feed into your combat and quests is just as satisfying. There's a good mix of more active and passive tasks you can do, so if you want to sit down and play for a bit there's some things to micromanage, and when you don't have as much time you can just click on a skill and leave it to idle. 

Best of all, there's no pay to win or "speed up" boosts. You pay once and get the whole game. Because of this they don't burden you down with artificially slow grinds to push you to pay. The game is balanced around fun with reasonable goals (unless you want to 100% in which case look at my play time >.>).

negative.review:
Lacks the appeal of both Runescape and idle games.

I haven't played much RS but I'm under the impression that most players are initially hooked in by completing quests and exploring the world, and only find themselves obsessively grinding firemaking levels after they've already become invested in the game. Melvor doesn't have any content like that, and it expects you to start grinding for grinding's sake as soon you finish the short tutorial. I probably wouldn't have played this for more than a few hours if I hadn't spent money on it - sunk cost fallacy and all that.
Some people might think that all idle games are just grinding for grinding's sake. That's not entirely wrong, but as someone who's spend an embarrassing amount of playing idle games the good ones typically have other features that make them interesting, such as "unfolding" systems, complex buildcrafting, and really big numbers. Melvor doesn't have anything like those. There's also a few annoying decisions (like not being able to idle combat during the early game and having to manually swap between crafting intermediate items for fletching) that probably only exist because Melvor wasn't designed from the ground up as an original idle game but rather as an idle clone of RS.

Melvor feels less like RS [i]reimagined[/i] as an idle game and more like RS [i]stripped down[/i] into an idle game - without anything being added in the process. That would be fine, except RS is free(-ish) and Melvor isn't. I wouldn't recommend Melvor unless you already like RS but don't want to actually play it for whatever reason.

P.S: This game makes you log into an external account to play it, but has no online features. This is pretty crappy, and I'd consider leaving a bad review over it even if the game was decent.

A peculiar game. Melvor Idle is all about "numbers go up" combined with an progression system that offers various small bonuses to different areas of the gameplay. 

In the beginning, your first decision will be what skill you want to start with. Chop trees to gather wood for crafting, mine ore for smithing or go fish for cooking? There are quite a few strategies to get your character off the ground, make some money and get those bonuses going. 

In the late game, all those potions you brewed, summoning tablets you crafted, agility obstacles you build and astrological constellations you studied will give you quite a productivity boost in whatever skill you're practicing at that point.

But to reach that point is just... so... tedious. 

When you train a skill, you select a single task and your character... will repeat that task. Over and over. Unless you're specifically micro managing your crafting steps to create a specific item, the majority of Melvor Idle is just... well, idle.

But, not in a particularly interesting way, if that makes sense?

It's an "idler's idle game", for lack of a better term. It's not a game that you can play [i]choosing[/i] to run it on a second screen and see a smooth progression when you shut down your PC two hours later. Rather, those two hours will have barely made a dent into the time you need to invest into it. The game features offline-progression for up to 24 hours, but if your character ran out of resources during that time, then you get interrupted and whatever progression you would have made is lost. So when you're crafting bows, better make sure you have stockpiled enough of the specific kind of wood you need to not run out. After that, you need to buy enough bowstring to complete the bows you started, but using a different crafting task.

And that's just in one skill. There are about a dozen skills with at least a dozen items to craft each. There are many monsters to fight, many items to loot and many small steps to progress. Which is impressive, in the grand scheme of things. If you like spreadsheeting your games and planning your progression, then I can imagine you can draw quite some enjoyment out of it, if you can get used to the sometimes clunky UI.

But for me, the game quickly began to feel like work rather than play. A daily grind. Log in one to two times to collect my offline progression, check what my current goal is and what items/stats I need to reach it, maybe switch the skill I'm currently training. Repeat the next day.

The friend who initially recommended the game to me lasted about a month before unceremoniously dropping it, having only completed the first two of about a dozen dungeons. Meanwhile I, probably being a bit too tenacious for my own good, have been progressing through the game for two years now. At least I can write this review after having seen everything the game has to offer. 

Except the DLCs, which would dump even more skill levels, items and empty progression logs on my plate. No thanks, I'm good.

To think that Melvor Idle is an idle version of Runescape. I know what game I will never touch with a ten foot pole.

I probably wouldn't have played this for more than a few hours if I hadn't spent money on it - sunk cost fallacy and all that.
Some people might think that all idle games are just grinding for grinding's sake. That's not entirely wrong, but as someone who's spend an embarrassing amount of playing idle games the good ones typically have other features that make them interesting, such as "unfolding" systems, complex buildcrafting, and really big numbers. Melvor doesn't have anything like those. There's also a few annoying decisions (like not being able to idle combat during the early game and having to manually swap between crafting intermediate items for fletching) that probably only exist because Melvor wasn't designed from the ground up as an original idle game but rather as an idle clone of RS.

Melvor feels less like RS [i]reimagined[/i] as an idle game and more like RS [i]stripped down[/i] into an idle game - without anything being added in the process. That would be fine, except RS is free(-ish) and Melvor isn't. I wouldn't recommend Melvor unless you already like RS but don't want to actually play it for whatever reason.

P.S: This game makes you log into an external account to play it, but has no online features. This is pretty crappy, and I'd consider leaving a bad review over it even if the game was decent.

A peculiar game. Melvor Idle is all about "numbers go up" combined with an progression system that offers various small bonuses to different areas of the gameplay. 

In the beginning, your first decision will be what skill you want to start with. Chop trees to gather wood for crafting, mine ore for smithing or go fish for cooking? There are quite a few strategies to get your character off the ground, make some money and get those bonuses going. 

In the late game, all those potions you brewed, summoning tablets you crafted, agility obstacles you build and astrological constellations you studied will give you quite a productivity boost in whatever skill you're practicing at that point.

But to reach that point is just... so... tedious. 

When you train a skill, you select a single task and your character... will repeat that task. Over and over. Unless you're specifically micro managing your crafting steps to create a specific item, the majority of Melvor Idle is just... well, idle.

But, not in a particularly interesting way, if that makes sense?

It's an "idler's idle game", for lack of a better term. It's not a game that you can play [i]choosing[/i] to run it on a second screen and see a smooth progression when you shut down your PC two hours later. Rather, those two hours will have barely made a dent into the time you need to invest into it. The game features offline-progression for up to 24 hours, but if your character ran out of resources during that time, then you get interrupted and whatever progression you would have made is lost. So when you're crafting bows, better make sure you have stockpiled enough of the specific kind of wood you need to not run out. After that, you need to buy enough bowstring to complete the bows you started, but using a different crafting task.

And that's just in one skill. There are about a dozen skills with at least a dozen items to craft each. There are many monsters to fight, many items to loot and many small steps to progress. Which is impressive, in the grand scheme of things. If you like spreadsheeting your games and planning your progression, then I can imagine you can draw quite some enjoyment out of it, if you can get used to the sometimes clunky UI.

But for me, the game quickly began to feel like work rather than play. A daily grind. Log in one to two times to collect my offline progression, check what my current goal is and what items/stats I need to reach it, maybe switch the skill I'm currently training. Repeat the next day.

The friend who initially recommended the game to me lasted about a month before unceremoniously dropping it, having only completed the first two of about a dozen dungeons. Meanwhile I, probably being a bit too tenacious for my own good, have been progressing through the game for two years now. At least I can write this review after having seen everything the game has to offer. 

Except the DLCs, which would dump even more skill levels, items and empty progression logs on my plate. No thanks, I'm good.

To think that Melvor Idle is an idle version of Runescape. I know what game I will never touch with a ten foot pole.

Lacks the appeal of both Runescape and idle games.

That's not entirely wrong, but as someone who's spend an embarrassing amount of playing idle games the good ones typically have other features that make them interesting, such as "unfolding" systems, complex buildcrafting, and really big numbers. Melvor doesn't have anything like those. There's also a few annoying decisions (like not being able to idle combat during the early game and having to manually swap between crafting intermediate items for fletching) that probably only exist because Melvor wasn't designed from the ground up as an original idle game but rather as an idle clone of RS.

Melvor feels less like RS [i]reimagined[/i] as an idle game and more like RS [i]stripped down[/i] into an idle game - without anything being added in the process. That would be fine, except RS is free(-ish) and Melvor isn't. I wouldn't recommend Melvor unless you already like RS but don't want to actually play it for whatever reason.

P.S: This game makes you log into an external account to play it, but has no online features. This is pretty crappy, and I'd consider leaving a bad review over it even if the game was decent.

I used to play this for long time when it was still free, and then came back to it. There are big issues i should mention:
- The offline idle time is limited to 24 hours. This is the killer move that makes me stop playing, Idleon among others lets you be off many years.
- Restricted to 1 active action at the time. This again goes against "standards" of all other idle games and makes this game annoying.

With both points combined, how is it possible the developer would still limit it only to 24 hours when there is only 1 thing to calculate/estimate? That's very little CPU time needed.
